III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Staff sufficiency
Title
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10123
Section (1) A facility shall have a staffing pattern of administrative,
Description supervisory, direct care, and other staff sufficient to perform the
prescribed functions required by these administrative rules and to
provide for the needs, protection, and supervision of the residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Staff provided a vape to youth at the facility during shower time
Investigation Administrator 1 and Supervisor 1 were interviewed face-to-
face at the facility on 12/6/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS
worker. Both reported being informed of the allegations on
12/4/2024 by Supervisor 2 who informed them (provided incident
report) Youth A told Supervisor 2 of the allegations. They also
reported conducting an internal investigation and having all but
two of the youth on the unit (Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, Youth D,
Youth E, and Youth F) deny any use of a vape. The incident was
described to them. Youth F informed Administrator 1 and
Supervisor 1 that Youth F overhead other youth talking about
vaping and smelling something “funny” like smoke on the pod.
Youth A reported to them Staff 1 would not allow Youth A to go
into the shower when it was Youth A’s turn until Staff 1 went into
the shower shutting the door behind Staff 1. A few moments later
Staff 1 came out of the shower and allowed Youth A into the
shower. They were also told Staff 1 did not stop any other youth
from going into the shower like Staff 1 did with Youth A.
Administrator 1 and Supervisor 1 reported the video recording
shows what Youth A reported to them. They also reported Staff 1
was the solo staff on the pod when going into the shower and
shutting the door behind himself. They also reported speaking with
Staff 1 who denied the allegations. Staff 1 is suspended until
further notice and was only hired about 2-months ago. The
reported Staff 1 developed a negative attitude and stated the
facility is “crazy” before leaving. They were asked about
Administrator 1 making the call to DHHS and he reported being
the only supervisor in the building after the internal investigation
was completed.
2

Supervisor 1 was interviewed again face-to-face at the facility
on 12/19/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He
reported Youth A, Youth E and Youth F have been released from
the program. He also provided a copy of the video recording of the
allegations.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
12/6/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported
knowing the reason for the interview because Youth A had to
“snitch” on Staff 1 because Staff 1 was doing something Youth A
doesn’t agree with. Youth A described this action by Staff 1 as
Staff 1 allowing “everyone to hit a vape in the shower”. Youth A
also reported Youth C was in the shower prior to Youth A and only
stayed in the shower for approximately 1 minute. Youth A reported
smelling the vape after Youth C came out of the shower and when
moving to enter the shower, Staff 1 stopped Youth A before Staff
1 went into the shower, shutting the door behind himself. Staff 1
told Youth A to use the second shower and before Youth A was
ready to enter the second shower, Staff 1 came out of the first
shower, gave the soap to Youth A and told Youth A, Youth A
could enter now. Just before entering the shower, Youth A heard
Youth C talking with Youth B and saying because Youth A is
“white”, Youth A will snitch on the group. Youth A reported later in
the shift, Staff 1 told Youth A that if Youth A “snitches” on Staff 1,
Staff 1 will be fired but will have fun on Staff 1’s last day. The
other youth (Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, and Youth E) began
calling Youth A “rat, narc, snitch”, and tried to bully Youth A since
the shower incident. Youth A also reported overhearing other
youth (Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, and Youth E) talking with Staff
1 about vaping. Youth A reported Staff 1 told these youth (Youth
B, Youth C, Youth D, and Youth E) that Staff 1 got the vape pen
back from Staff 1’s girlfriend. Youth A also reported a belief that
Staff 1 had been allowing youth to use a vape for a long time and
based this belief on the way Staff 1 had been talking with youth
about vaping and other youth on other pods want Staff 1 to work
with them. Further evidence to support this belief is Youth A
observing youth (Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, and Youth E) make
gestures of smoking a vape with Staff 1 but never observed any
youth nor Staff 1 use a vape. Youth A reported hearing Staff 1
talking about many inappropriate things with youth (no specific
youth identified) on the pod such as which female staff, Staff 1
finds attractive, drugs, and guns. Other things reported by Youth A
include observing Staff 1 show different youth (no one specifically
identified) pictures of Staff 1’s girlfriends, playing music for youth,
talking about wanting to “get” with some female staff, and showing
videos of youth smoking blunts with girls. Youth A also reported
3

Staff 1 looked up Youth A’s sister’s Instagram account and told
Youth A, Staff 1 doesn’t like white people. Youth A reported
feeling safe because Youth A was leaving later today.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
12/19/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth B
reported never observing a vape nor smelling vape smoke on the
pod. He also reported Staff 1 is Youth B’s favorite staff and Staff 1
would get the youth a job when they get out of the program. Youth
B denied any inappropriate behavior by Staff 1. Youth B also
reported feeling safe in the program and likes all the staff.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
12/19/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth C
reported knowing nothing about any vape use on the pod and has
never observed a vape on the pod. He also reported Staff 1 was
his favorite staff and Youth C denied Staff 1 gave youth any
favorite treatment. He denied Staff 1 ever showed anyone
anything on Staff 1’s phone. Youth C reported feeling safe at the
facility.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
12/19/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth D
denied any vape use on the pod and reported Staff 1 was fired for
no reason because Staff 1 was never inappropriate. He also
reported feeling safe at the facility.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed via phone on 12/19/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported being informed
of the allegations by Youth A and passing this information on to
Administrator 1 and Supervisor 1. She also reported after hearing
about the allegations, taking a male staff (did not give name) with
her to look on the pod for any evidence of vaping which Youth A
told her occurred the day before. She was informed that Youth A
needed to speak to a supervisor because Youth A called “central
control with his call button in the room. Youth A shared the
allegations with Supervisor 2 which became part of the internal
investigation by Administrator 1 and Supervisor 1. Supervisor 2
reported leaving before the investigation was over, so she was
unable to call Central Intake which Administrator 1 did. She also
reported after searching the pod, no vape was found.
Youth F was interviewed via phone on 1/27/2025. Youth F
reported never observing any staff or youth using a vape while in
the facility. He also reported never hearing youth talk about using
a vape. Youth F reported being asked about youth using a vape
4

by Administrator 1 a while ago and Youth F informed
Administrator 1 that Youth F had no knowledge about the vape.
Several attempts were made to contact Staff 1 but none were
successful. The attempts included:
• 12/10-1:00pm phone call, message left
• 12/19-9:45- phone call-Message left.
• 12/19-Home visit-4:20 pm, card left in door asking to call
back
Two attempts were made to contact Youth E but no call back was
received for the first call and the second call resulted in a
cancelled phone number.
Video Reviewed:
• The first video catches the whole pod from the south wall
where the camera is located. Staff 1 is observed standing
in a small group with Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, and Youth
E. As the group breaks up, Staff 1 walks to the shower door
and enters, shutting the door behind himself. The four
youth (Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, and Youth E) walk
around the pod and appear excited about something
(dancing and jumping around). 7-seconds later, Staff 1
comes back out of the shower.
• The second video is from the same angle but later in the
shower process. Staff 1 is observed stopped Youth A from
entering the shower and Staff 1 going into the shower for
approximately 7-seconds before coming back out.
Documents Reviewed:
• Youth A / Staff 1 Vape concerns Investigation dated
12/4/24 and authored by Administrator 1 and
Supervisor 1. This document outlines the internal
investigation completed by the facility after learning about
the allegations. It is documented in this report that Youth A
informed Administrator 1 and Supervisor 1 that Staff 1
allowed Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, and Youth E to “hit a
vape” while showering on 12/3/24. Administrator 1 and
Supervisor 1 reviewed the video and found it played out as
described by Youth A. Administrator 1 and Supervisor 1
interviewed Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, Youth E and Youth
F and received various reports from these interviewed
5

youth. Youth B reported having no knowledge of vaping,
Youth C reported something funny was going on in the
shower (no details were documented), Youth D was very
defensive and stated, “you’re not going to take down my
favorite staff with no proof”, Youth E reported having no
knowledge of the situation, and Youth F reported
something “smelled funny like smoke”. This report also
documented Staff 1 was informed of being suspended
(taken off shift) until the investigation was completed and a
report was made to MDHHS.
• 12/6/24 document written by Supervisor 1. It is outlined
in this document that Youth D requested to speak to
Supervisor 1 stating Youth D was “ready to tell the truth”.
Youth D is documented as stating Staff 1 experienced
“peer pressure” causing Staff 1 to allow the youth (no
specific youth identified in the report) to use the vape.
Youth D is also reported to have stated Staff 1 believed if
youth liked Staff 1 then Staff 1 had a better chance to earn
a full-time position at the facility.
• Incident Report Kalamazoo County Juvenile Home
dated 12/4/24 written by Supervisor 2. This document
outlines the incident as described by Youth A and told to
Supervisor 2. It is documented Supervisor 2 received a call
from Central Control around noon on 12/4/24 that Youth A
wanted to speak to Supervisor 2 about a staff doing
something inappropriate with other youth. Youth A informed
Supervisor 2 a belief that Staff 1 had placed a vape pen in
the shower allowing other youth (Youth B, Youth C, Youth
D, and Youth E) to vape except for Youth A and Youth F.
Youth A also stated Youth A had not observed any youth
nor Staff 1 use the vape and had not observed a vape pen.
Youth A also informed Supervisor 2 that Staff 1 stopped
Youth A from going into the shower when it was Youth A’s
turn, and Staff 1 was only in the shower for seconds before
allowing Youth A into the shower.
• Kalamazoo County Juvenile Home policy 2.13
Smoking/Chewing Tobacco. It is outlined in this
documented that staff and youth are not permitted to
smoke, vape, or chew tobacco on the premises. Staff and
youth are also not permitted to smoke, vape, or chew in
control units or other resident living areas. Staff are not
permitted to smoke, vape, or chew in county vehicles. Staff
are not permitted to give vape materials, cigarettes, or
chew to youth. The Juvenile Home is a smoke free
environment.
6

• Kalamazoo County Juvenile Home policy 2.14
Telephone/Electronic Equipment. It is outlined in this
document that staff are not to take or make personal phone
calls on a personal cell phone when supervising youth.
Staff are allowed to view text messages or listen to voice
messages when the time is appropriate but doing so while
supervising youth is highly discouraged.
• Kalamazoo County Juvenile Home policy 2.18
Professional Boundaries: Employee Relationships with
youth and their family members. It is outlined in this
document that staff are to develop and maintain
professional boundaries with youth in the program and for
two years after the youth leaves the program. Examples of
inappropriate boundaries are listed as discussing facility
business with youth, discussing staff issues or concerns,
disclosing personal information with youth, developing
friendships with youth, and several other situations.
• Kalamazoo County Juvenile Home policy 5.6 Safety &
Security - Security Checks/Supervision. It is
documented in this policy that youth must be always
visually/or auditorily supervised by staff. It is also
documented Youth must be visually monitored whenever
released from their rooms.
• Staff 1 HR record was reviewed, and no disciplinary
action was documented in the file. His orientation was
completed as required and he was up to date on training
requirements.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as evidence by interviews with
staff, written documentation, and video recordings. Although, it is
suspected that Staff 1 had indeed engaged in something
inappropriate, this interview had no direct evidence of Staff 1
allowing the youth in his charge to use a vape. Only one youth
reported this without observing the use of a vape and another
youth changed the story to suggest a vape was used (by youth)
and provided by Staff 1.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
7

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
